title: What makes us human in the age of AI? A philosophical deep dive
description:
What makes us human?

As artificial intelligence becomes more fluent, capable, and eerily human-like, this question takes on new urgency. Is being human just about sentience, intelligence, and memory ‚Äî qualities a machine can mimic ‚Äî or is there something deeper?

In this long-form philosophical essay, I explore what it means to be human through the insights of Pascal, Montaigne, Descartes, Hobbes, and Locke, and ask how AI forces us to rethink ourselves.

Along the way we‚Äôll consider:

Pascal‚Äôs haunting claim that we only love one another for ‚Äúborrowed qualities.‚Äù

Montaigne‚Äôs vision of the self as always in flux and contradiction.

How early modern thinkers used primary and secondary qualities to define reality.

Why AI may look human on the surface, but lacks the inner opacity of lived experience.

This is not a video about how close AI is to being human ‚Äî but about how AI helps reveal what we already take for granted about ourselves.

üìå If you‚Äôre interested in philosophy, theology, and the big questions raised by new technology, you‚Äôre in the right place.

title: Should We Care About AI Welfare?
description:
Can artificial intelligence have welfare? Could a machine deserve care?

In this video essay, I explore Anthropic‚Äôs recent move to let its Claude models end abusive conversations: a design choice framed as a ‚Äúlow-cost safeguard‚Äù in case AI systems turn out to have morally significant states. But this isn‚Äôt just about the future of AI ‚Äî it‚Äôs about us.

Along the way we‚Äôll meet:
Medieval pigs on trial and Athenian axes banished for murder üêñ‚öñÔ∏è
Burberry and brand personality üëî
Thomas Hobbes on personation, Foucault on askƒìsis, and Paul Ricoeur on the ‚Äúas if‚Äù ü§ù
Augustine‚Äôs Confessions, where love itself is a gravitational force üí´

The question of ‚ÄúAI welfare‚Äù isn‚Äôt science fiction. It‚Äôs about what kind of moral ecosystem we are building now ‚Äî through our speech, our habits, and our social fictions.

So: should we treat AIs ‚Äúas if‚Äù they matter, not because they are persons, but because of what such practices do to us?

#AIethics #Philosophy #AnthropicClaude

title: Jean Luc Nancy and the Deconstruction of Christianity: A conversation with Ashok Collins
description:
This interview with Dr Ashok Collins (Australian National University) about his book "Jean-Luc Nancy and the Deconstruction of Christianity" was recorded in July 2025.

The conversation between Dr Collins and A/Prof Christopher Watkin, editor of the Crosscurrents series, ranges over topics including:

* what led Dr. Collins to write this book
* the primary debates the book intervenes in
* the polemical debate between John Caputo and Martin H√§gglund over Derrida, deconstruction, and religion
* The concept of ‚Äòfiguration‚Äô, which is central to Collins's approach
* the relation of the figural to literary and allegorical readings of religious texts
* Dr. Collins's plans for future work

The book is available from https://edinburghuniversitypress.com/book-jean-luc-nancy-and-the-deconstruction-of-christianity.html

title: Jordan Peterson & Tim Keller: Two Visions of identity and meaning
description:
üé• We Need to Talk About Hierarchy: Jordan Peterson, Tim Keller, and Jacob‚Äôs Ladder

What happens when you fall‚Äîand no longer have the strength to climb?

In this video we explore a striking juxtaposition: Jordan Peterson's existential interpretation of Jacob‚Äôs ladder from Genesis 28, and Timothy Keller‚Äôs gospel-centered reading of the same passage. One sees the ladder as the call to ascend‚Äîthrough moral striving, order, and responsibility. The other sees it as the architecture of grace‚Äîa vision of a God who descends.

Drawing on two remarkable talks‚ÄîPeterson‚Äôs conversation with John Vervaeke and Jordan Hall, and Keller‚Äôs 2001 sermon ‚ÄúThe Openness of Heaven‚Äù‚Äîwe investigate what these two thinkers reveal not only about the biblical text, but about two profoundly different understandings of human nature, morality, hope, and the shape of ultimate reality.

üìå In this video, we reflect on:
* Why hierarchy is such a powerful‚Äîand dangerous‚Äîmetaphor for the moral life
* How Peterson‚Äôs vision of truth, responsibility, and ascent has given meaning to many adrift in a chaotic world
* Why Keller‚Äôs vision of grace, descent, and divine initiative might offer a deeper, more stable foundation
* The psychological, theological, and existential implications of trying to ‚Äúearn‚Äù your meaning
* How the Bible overturns every worldly ladder‚Äîmoral, social, and spiritual‚Äîby proclaiming a God who comes down

This is not just a theological debate‚Äîit‚Äôs a deeply human question: Are we meant to climb our way to wholeness? Or are we meant to be carried, even when we cannot climb?

Whether you‚Äôre a Peterson enthusiast, a Keller admirer, or just someone thinking seriously about meaning and morality, you‚Äôre warmly invited into this thoughtful exploration.

üìñ ‚ÄúSurely the Lord is in this place, and I was not aware of it.‚Äù ‚Äî Genesis 28:16

title: Jordan Peterson, Russell Brand, and the modern quest for a unified self
description:
What does it mean to be a unified self? In a recent conversation, Jordan Peterson and Russell Brand wrestled with one of the most pressing philosophical and existential questions of our time: how do we integrate our scattered, divided selves into something coherent and whole?

Peterson and Brand offer two answers‚Äîone rooted in desire and power, the other in voluntary self-sacrifice. But is there a third, deeper, and more transformative way? This video takes their discussion further, revealing a richer, more existentially satisfying path that challenges the assumptions underlying both their positions.

Drawing from Nietzsche, Freud, Descartes, Montaigne, and Augustine, this analysis uncovers the hidden logic of power at work in both hedonism and self-discipline, and explores how the Christian tradition offers an alternative not based on possession, but on dispossession‚Äîa paradoxical path to true selfhood.

Topics discussed include
üîπ The dangers of defining the self through desire or self-sacrifice
üîπ How Descartes‚Äô rationalism and Montaigne‚Äôs skepticism mirror Peterson‚Äôs two models
üîπ Augustine‚Äôs radical vision: unity through doxological dispossession
üîπ Why true selfhood isn‚Äôt about maximizing power, but about transcendent transformation.

This is not simply a critique of Jorddan Peterson and Russell Brand, indeed there is wisdom in much of what they say. It is a response to their provocation, an invitation to rethink what it means to be a self, to move beyond the logic of control and power, and to embrace an identity shaped not by the parts of our selves we privilege, but by a wholeness we receive.

Join us as we explore the profound implications of this debate for philosophy, theology, and the modern search for meaning.

üëâ Like, comment, and subscribe for more deep dives into philosophy, theology, and culture!

#JordanPeterson #RussellBrand #Philosophy #Christianity #Identity #Selfhood #Existentialism #Nietzsche #Augustine #Theology

title: Common sense, its history and ideology. #2: Descartes and the Three Paradoxes of Common Sense
description:
This video takes a deep dive into the opening paragraph of Part I of Ren√© Descartes's "Discourse on Method", discussing three paradoxes that structure the ideology of common sense:
1) The paradox of the local and the universal: is common sense something that everybody has, or that only a few people possess? 
2) The paradox of the natural and the artificial: is common sense something we are born with, or something we have to cultivate and make for ourselves?
3) The paradox of expertise: is common sense the fruit of learning and expertise, or does it subvert and call those things into question?
These three paradoxes help us to understand how common sense functions as a crucial feature of modern political and social discourse.

title: Common sense, its history and ideology. #1: Origins
description: In this first in a new series of videos I trace the history and ideology of the idea of common sense. This first video begins the story with discussions of Aristotle, Aquinas and Descartes.

title: The Unicorn Tapestries as a parable of the commons
description:
The Unicorn Tapestries are a series of seven huge tapestries hanging in the Cloisters of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Unicorn_Tapestries
Although their order is contested, they seem to depict the hunting and eventual killing of a unicorn with magical powers, and possibly its resurrection or afterlife in an ethereal, heavenly realm.
In this video I use the stages of the hunt depicted in the different tapestries as a starting point for reflections on the cultural commons and enclosure. I am not claiming that the ideas I discuss were intended by those who originally commissioned or wove the tapestries but that, viewed from a modern perspective, the series unfolds a powerful commentary on the symbolic and material commons, enclosure, and the intricate relations between the common, the public and the private.

title: Jordan Peterson, Ezra Klein and Kevin Vanhoozer on knowledge and persuasion
description: This video discusses what I'm calling "the Klein problem": the idea that we can't be sure that our own convictions and beliefs have been formed on a sound basis. Ezra Klein, Jordan Peterson and Kevin Vanhoozer all discuss this problem, drawing different conclusions about it. It's a problem of persuasion and persuadability, which is at the heart of democracy.

title: Jordan Peterson and Herman Dooyeweerd on the Bible and Narrative
description:
The second video in which I reflect on Jordan Peterson's book We Who Wrestle with God. 
In this clip I compare the way Peterson reads the Bible to the concept of ground-motives in the early twentieth-century Dutch theologian Herman Dooyeweerd.
Peterson reads the Bible through the lens of the dichotomy of order and chaos, which for Dooyeweerd is a form/matter ground-motive, whereas the Bible itself follows a creation-fall-redemption ground-motive.
This tension leaves Peterson with a cramped and repetitive understanding of the narrative arc of Scripture.

title: AI podcasts, disgust, and the ecosystem of thought
description:
A reflection on negative reactions to AI-generated podcasts, and where this new genre fits in the broader ecosystem of the way we process and summarise ideas.
Negative reactions to AI-generated audio reveal something about the way we use language more broadly. It's not only AI content where we find ourselves asking "whose words are these"?

title: French Technological Thought and the Nonhuman Turn: A conversation with Madeleine Chalmers
description:
This interview with Dr Madeleine Chalmers (Leicester University) about her book "French Technological Thought and the Nonhuman Turn" was recorded in October 2024.

The conversation between Dr Chalmers and A/Prof Christopher Watkin, editor of the Crosscurrents series, ranges over topics including:

* the primary debates the book intervenes in
* the concept of "technologos"
* the idea of "technics" in modern French thought
* the "nonhuman turn" in recent thought and culture
* the notion of "originary technicity"
* the influence of Catholic sacramentality on technological thinking
* a critique of the idea of a "reduction to signification" in the nonhuman turn

The book is open access and available free from https://edinburghuniversitypress.com/book-french-technological-thought-and-the-nonhuman-turn.html

title: The State of Nature and the Shaping of Modernity: Introduction
description:
An introduction to the book "The State of Nature and the Shaping of Modernity: Tracing the Roots of Colonialism, Secularity, and Ecology", forthcoming with Cambridge University Press in 2025.
In this video, the first in a new series and rather longer than the others, I read the book's Introduction, entitled "The State of Nature We're In", setting the scene for its context and argument.

The Introduction explores the concept of the "state of nature" as a cornerstone of modern Western thought, influencing how the West perceives human nature, colonialism, secularity, and ecology. Examining foundational theorists like Hobbes, Locke, and Rousseau, I argue that the state of nature reflects the fragmented, contradictory narratives that shape Western modernity, and takes us to the heart of contemporary culture wars. Hobbes depicted the state of nature as chaotic and brutal, while Rousseau saw it as idyllic but corrupted by society, and these diverse views underpin contemporary debates, revealing deep cultural tensions about identity, legitimacy, and progress. The book aims to dissect the state of nature motif, highlighting its ongoing ideological and cultural significance.

Chapters:
10:25 Whose state of nature? Which Modernity?
14:19 Hobbes Lite
29:47 Rousseau Lite
40:12 No State of Nature 
55:09 Western Modernity en abyme in the State of Nature 
1:04:52 The Argument of this Book

title: Bulk create, name, share and populate Google docs from a list of names and email addresses
description:
In this video I show you how to take a list of names and email addresses and in one click:
* create a Google doc for each name in the list,
* share each Google doc with the corresponding email,
* give the document a unique name corresponding to the name on your list,
* populate each document with a template of your design
* create a list of links to the documents  with the link text as each student name, that you can cut and paste into your LMS

The link referred to in the video is: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1MiJshdR4zQhXIrUm2H9kUI86fx6pSTF_KOBoPO13_rc/edit?usp=sharing

I'm planning to use it to create unique Google docs for students in my units. It can create hundreds of bespoke docs in one click. I hope this can save you some time!

title: The Social Contract of Higher Education, Faith-Based Higher Education Summit, Canberra, October 2023
description:
This talk was part of the inaugural Faith-Based Higher Education Summit held in the Main Committee Room of Parliament House, Canberra, on 30 October 2023. Sponsored by Minister for Education Hon Jason Clare MP, the Summit brought together a broad coalition of representatives from Buddhist, Christian, Hindu, Jewish and Muslim communities in Australia to discuss the future of Australian faith-based higher education.
In addition to hearing from Minister Clare, the Summit was addressed by Senator Sarah Henderson,  Shadow Minister for Education, and Senator Deborah O'Neill, Deputy Co-Chair ALP National Policy Forum.

description:

The Google sheet can be found at https://bit.ly/studentfbsheet

title: Michel Serres and the Parasitic Unmaking of Modernity
description:
This is the audio of a talk I gave at the International Philosophical Seminar (IPS) in June 2022. It begins by showing how Michel Serres rethinks the foundational modern moment of the state of nature, and it then sketches a way of understanding modernity in terms of three recurring moments: a flattening, a division and a hierarchy, showing how Michel Serres's thought disrupts each of these moments through its motif of parasitism. 

Photograph ‚í∏ achresis khora, https://www.flickr.com/photos/26774111@N00/

title: How Michel Serres Thinks
description:
This is a recording of a paper I gave at the conference "Michel Serres: Thinking Beyond Boundaries" at the Maison Fran√ßaise d'Oxford on 16 June 2022.
Paper abstract: 
In this paper I explore not what Michel Serres thinks about this or that subject, but how he thinks about everything. I show that his thought has a distinct character and power that stands alongside contemporaries such as Derrida, Deleuze and Foucault in its importance, but distinguishes itself from them in its approach and potential. I identify three ways in which Serres's thought is distinctive, and frame them in terms of the three images of a path, a window and a cave, corresponding to the ideas that he thinks combinatorially rather than analytically, ecologically rather than dualistically, and prepositionally rather than substantively. After describing each image I briefly sketch how Serres‚Äôs way of thinking offers crucial and unique insights into some of the most important issues we face today.

title: "The Ukraine Crisis" by Marko Pavlyshyn, Emeritus Professor of Ukrainian Studies
description:
"The Ukraine Crisis: Where Are We Now, and How Did We Get Here? With Some Reflections on the Issues the Crisis Raises for the Engaged Researcher", by Marko Pavlyshyn, Emeritus Professor of Ukrainian Studies, Monash University, and Director of the Mykola Zerov Centre for Ukrainian Studies from 2004 to 2019 at Monash Arts

On 16 March 2022 I had the honour of attending a lecture given by Prof. Marko Pavlyshyn, one of Australia's foremost experts on Ukrainian culture and politics, and a former colleague at Monash University. With Marko's permission, I took a video of his lecture and post it here. I found it to provide a depth of understanding about current events that is rare in the daily news cycle, and Marko's reflections on the implications of the Russian invasion for Arts and Humanities faculties were particularly illuminating and challenging.
The video of Marko's lecture is followed by audio of his response to a question I asked about the particular role for arts and humanities scholars in responding to the invasion.

Abstract:¬†
In this talk I‚Äôll try to combine two rather disparate things. The first is a description of the Russian-Ukrainian War as it appears to me on the day of the seminar, together with ambitiously brief sketches of the relevant short-term and long-term antecedent contexts and of already existing and potential repercussions.The second is an account of some of the questions that have posed themselves to me as I have tried to balance my personal intellectual and emotional investment in the issue, the ideal of objectivity, the media imperatives of brevity and clarity, and my ongoing inner debate about the ethical grounds of postcolonial studies.Then we can all go to breakfast.

title: Our fractured state of nature: environment, emancipation, ecnonomy
description:
This is a recording of a paper given at the Australasian Society of Continental Philosophy Conference, December 2021.

Paper title
"Artificial state of nature: how an aporia of myth shapes our experience of emancipation and the market"

Abstract
This paper argues that there are two contradictory modern Western understandings of nature, vividly captured in the social contract theories of Thomas Hobbes and Jean-Jacques Rousseau respectively. These theories borrow the logic of the theological "fourfold state" of humanity, but we are no longer clear today how we can be saved. These very different concepts of nature give rise to two incompatible paradigms for engaging with the natural world, two incompatible accounts of the modern West's most fundamental value: freedom, and two radically different views of the market, which itself acts like a second nature. The paper argues that we must both recognise this incompatiblity, and that we will de facto make a choice between these concepts. Perhaps a way of reconciling them can be found by returning to the theological narrative on which they both draw.

title: Where is Rousseau's State of Nature?
description:
This is a recording of a paper I gave at the 2021 Australian Society of French Studies Conference.

Paper title
Siting Rousseau‚Äôs state of Nature

Abstract
Rousseau‚Äôs account of the social contract relies, both logically and rhetorically, on his reconstruction of the so-called ‚Äústate of nature‚Äù, a supposed pre-contractual condition of human life. There is much debate about whether or not Rousseau intends his state of nature to describe a historically and geographically ‚Äúreal‚Äù situation, but this paper argues that focusing on the question of the state of nature‚Äôs historicity misses both its power and its danger. The paper argues that the more important question is how the state of nature, as a non-site, serves to construct a social imaginary in which certain political relations become possible and desirable. Approaching the Rousseauian state of nature as a site, a topos, the paper reflects on the power of non-sites to shape social and political spaces today, drawing on contemporary reaffirmations and rejections of the state of nature idea. The state of nature is a site that continues to influence debates about ecology and the colonial legacy. The argument has implications for other contemporary non-sites such as the perfectly free market, the society of radical equality and the dystopia of looming Fascism.

title: Advice on securing a large academic grant
description:
Writing successful applications for academic grants and fellowships is really hard. I have been asked a few times in recent months what advice I would give to colleagues applying for competitive grants and fellowships, such as the Australian Research Council Discovery Project or Future Fellowship schemes.
While my expertise is limited to my own experience and my one-time success in the Future Fellowship scheme, I'm more than happy to share what I have learned in the hope that someone might find it useful.
This video is a recording of a seminar I gave in July 2021, with particular reference to the ARC Future Fellowship scheme, a four-year research fellowship (for more information see https://www.arc.gov.au/grants/discovery-program/future-fellowships).

Find out more about my research at https://christopherwatkin.com

title: 4 hour babbling brook pomodoro, relaxing study aid with 8x25 min timer for work, HD
description:
This is the third in a series of nature sounds pomodoro study aids I will post on this channel. Please remember to subscribe for new videos. Channel: http://www.youtube.com/channel/UCjhGOouhxdPo0XkspFSs2Dw?sub_confirmation=1

The video combines two of the study and work aids that have helped me relax and concentrate over the years: nature sounds and the pomodoro technique (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pomodoro_Technique)

You can use the video to structure a pomodoro study session in two ways:
1) listen out for the distinctive cuckoo call at the end of every 25 minute study session and every 5 minute break.
2) follow the discrete countdown timer in the top left-hand corner of the video, telling you how long remains in every 25 minute study session and 5 minute break.

Enjoy!

title: Rewriting the Social Contract: The Role of Christian Social Institutions
description:
This talk was delivered at Parliament House, Canberra, on 22 February 2021, at the invitation of the Church Community Restoration Project (CCRP), an alliance of Christian charitable organisations committed to supporting the reovery of Australian communities in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. I am very grateful to the CCRP for inviting me to be their guest lecturer.

The talk was part of a day of discussions organised by the CCRP with leading government and opposition politicians, including PM Scott Morrison and Leader of the Opposition Anthony Albanese, whose address to the CCRP is available here: 
https://anthonyalbanese.com.au/anthony-albanese-speech-address-to-the-church-community-restoration-project-parliament-house-canberra-monday-22-february-2021

The CCRP also issued a "Joint Letter from Christian Leaders in Relation to Community Restoration", a copy of which is available here: https://d3nr8uzk0yq0qe.cloudfront.net/media/documents/Church_community_restoration_project_-_Joint_communique.pdf

A written version of this talk is available here:
https://christopherwatkin.com/2021/02/23/talk-rewriting-the-social-contract-the-role-of-christian-social-institutionsrewriting-the-social-contract-the-role-of-christian-social-institutions/

title: Michel Serres and the New Social Contract
description:
This is a paper presented at the 2020 SEP-FEP (Society for European Philosophy and Forum for European Philosophy) conference: https://sep-fep.com/

Abstract:
One of Michel Serres‚Äôs best-known works in the anglophone world is The Natural Contract, in which he argues that our current social contract dangerously neglects the non-human and needs supplementing with a new settlement that incorporates ecological interests. Prescient when it was first published in 1990, this paper argues that The Natural Contract is an indispensable document for making sense of the increasing calls in the wake of COVID-19 for a new social contract. How can Serres‚Äôs natural contract specifically, and his thought more broadly, help us to come to terms with the historical moment in which we find ourselves? This paper will use Serres‚Äôs reflections both on the social and natural contracts across a number of works to help us understand what a social contract is (and isn‚Äôt!), how it can be a tool both for change and exclusion, and how we can best respond to contemporary demands for its renewal.

You can find my interview on "Michel Serres, Philosophy and the Contemporary World" for the conference here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=73C9UzHQzYw

For more content on Michel Serres, see https://christopherwatkin.com/category/michel-serres/
For more reflections on the social contract, see https://christopherwatkin.com/category/social-contract/

Can you tell that the paper was recorded at midnight Melbourne time?!

title: Michel Serres, Philosophy and the Contemporary World
description:
An interview prepared for the 2020 SEP-FEP Conference, with David Webb and Christopher Watkin
Topics include Serres's style, politics, ecology, language, and my book Michel Serres: Figures of Thought (Edinburgh University Press, 2020):  https://www.amazon.com/Michel-Serres-Introduction-Christopher-Watkin/dp/1474405746/

The¬†SEP-FEP¬†conference is the largest annual event of its kind in Europe, aiming to bring together researchers, teachers and students from different disciplines, interested in all areas of contemporary European philosophy. In 2020, to mark the passing of Michel Serres last June, the conference features a strand of presentations devoted to his work.
You can read more about my work on Serres at https://christopherwatkin.com/category/michel-serres/, and my more systematic introduction to his thought in a seminar delivered at Stanford in February 2020 is available at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0q8bo3RL0ik.

title: COVID 19 and the social contract
description:
How does the COVID-19 lockdown reveal the nature of our social contract?
For the full blog post, see https://christopherwatkin.com/2020/06/19/covid-19-and-the-social-contract/

title: The Ends of Autonomy Colloquium  Introduction
description:
This video introduces the 'Ends of Autonomy' colloquium co-hosted by Prof Oliver Davis (Warwick) and Dr Christopher Watkin (Monash), 7-9 July.

The colloquium, and the broader research project of which it is part, analyse how new social, scientific and technological realities are changing our understanding of freedom, and explore how we can develop new accounts of freedom that empower citizens to make informed decisions about their liberty. The dominant modern concept of individual autonomy was not designed for today‚Äôs world of extremism, surveillance, big data, climate change and global public health, all of which complicate its emancipatory axis of oppression and liberation. Yet a sense that we have been freed from past oppressions remains fundamental to our self-construction as individuals and to the collective identity of modern Western societies.

this project brings together a cross-disciplinary group of researchers from the arts, humanities and social sciences to investigate how concepts of freedom have developed historically and to consider whether they can and should continue to change in response to emerging social challenges and if so, how. 

The four foci for the project are:
(i) the history of freedom, autonomy, emancipation and liberation
(ii) the impact of technology (including AI, big data, and 'algorithmic governmentality')
(iii) sustainability, climate and freedom
(iv) surveillance, extremism and freedom

If you would like to be added to the mailing list for future 'Ends of Autonomy' announcements, including news about the December 2020 Zoom conference and videos of selected talks from the July event, please DM @DrChrisWatkin.

https://warwick.ac.uk/fac/arts/modernlanguages/research/french/currentprojects/beyondautonomy

title: ThoughtCatcher, the app that makes it easy to record, rank and remember your most important ideas
description:
This is the first look at an app I'm developing to help people who want a simple and effective way to capture thoughts, quotes and insights on the go. 

You can rank your thoughts in an upvote knock-out tournament, and as your library of ideas grows your most important insights will always remain on top.
You can import and export groups of thoughts or quotes, and archive old thoughts.

EASE OF USE
ThoughtCatcher is built on two simple principles:
     - make it as easy as possible to record a new thought, quote or insight right from the start screen
     - make it as quick and fun as possible to rank thoughts and remember the most important ones.
That's it. No complex hierarchies. No folder structures. No color coding. Just you and your thoughts, ranked by their importance to you.

ORDER BY UPVOTING
* Reviewing and ranking thoughts is as easy as one tap. 
* Your ideas are automatically grouped in pairs, and you tap one thought from each pair to go through to the next round. However many thoughts you have, eventually you end up with one most important one on top, and a pyramid in descending order of importance to you. 
* Your thoughts remain ordered in one simple hierarchy at all times, and adding new thoughts is always straightforward and hassle free.
* It's a knock-out tournament for your creative mind, and each review and ranking helps you remember your most important thoughts.

PERSONAL GROWTH
* Use ThoughtCatcher to grow and organise your collection of personal development quotations, and to cultivate the discipline of recording your insights about your life, work or the world.

INSPIRATION
* Feed your inspiration by importing one of the banks of famous thoughts from christopherwatkin.com [coming soon]

FLEXIBILITY
* Catch your thoughts by typing, by cutting and pasting from websites, or through text-to-speech dictation on your smartphone.

COMPATIBILITY
* Importing or exporting ideas in bulk is as easy as cut and paste. Transfer thoughts from other apps with ease, without the need for complex file formats. And you can always get all your data out of ThoughtCatcher whenever you want.

PRIVACY
* ThoughtCatcher is completely private. The only copy of your thoughts is on your own device, until you choose to export them. No servers, no data sharing. You are in control of your own data.

http://christopherwatkin.com/ThoughtCatcher/

title: Not more of the same: Michel Serres and Alterity. 2020 version
description:
DEAKIN UNIVERSITY PHILOSOPHY SEMINAR, August 29, 2017

The themes of difference and alterity are commonly thought to characterise French thought in the second half of the twentieth century, with canonical thinkers such as L√©vinas, Derrida and, latterly, Nancy elaborating diverse ethical positions that nevertheless each accord a privileged and positive place to otherness. In recent years, however, a new philosophy of sameness has emerged, most prominently in the thought of Alain Badiou, claiming that the ethics of alterity is bankrupt, disingenuous and dangerous, and that it is identity and sameness, not difference and alterity, that are of positive ethical value. In this talk I introduce into this debate the thought of Michel Serres, in the light of which we can see that Badiou shares more in common with his supposed opponents than either he or they are ready to admit. For all that distinguishes Badiou‚Äôs position from that of his antagonists, they share the fundamental assumption that either identity or difference should be coded positively, but not both equally. In a move more radical than Badiou‚Äôs own intervention, Serres offers a different account, one in which neither sameness nor difference is ethically privileged over the other. Couched in the language of asymmetry, parasitism, inclination and enantiomorphy, Serres‚Äôs approach shows us how we can move on from the conflict between identity and alterity to a more scientifically informed and, I argue, more ethically compelling account of the relation between identity and alterity.

In this new 2020 version I have improved the sound quality of the video, which is the original 2017 recording.

PDF handout: https://christopherwatkin.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Chris-Watkin-More-of-the-Same-Michel-Serres-and-the-Question-of-Alterity-in-Recent-French-Thought-handout.pdf

Link to video on my website: https://christopherwatkin.com/2017/08/30/youtube-video-paper-michel-serres-question-alterity-recent-french-thought-improved-audio/

title: Samuel Beckett, Krapp's Last Tape: Literature And Modernism lecture 2020
description:
I made this lecture for my students in the Literature and Modernism unit at Moansh University. Beckett came at the end of the course, after weeks on Andr√© Breton, Jean Cocteau, Leonora Carrington, Lu Xun, Eileen Chang, Ding Ling, and Jean Rhys.
There is talk in university circles these days of the lecture format being dead. I think that's a naive view, like saying radio is dead because of the invention of television. 
So in addition to helping my students understand Beckett, I wanted to see what I could do with a 50 minute "lecture" slot under lockdown. I gave myself an afternoon and an evening to produce the finished product (which encoded overnight and was uploaded the next morning) from notes I had written in a previous year.
After receiving feedback from students who watched the "lecture", I'm more convinced than ever that "young people" today are more than capable of sitting for 50 minutes and consuming information, providing it is presented with some thoughtfulness. 
To abandon the 50 minute concentration span is, in my opinion, to concede too much territory to a troubling ideology that assumes a thinking elite will manage the attention of the rest of the population for their own ends. Teaching students to have their attention managed by other people is a problematic way to prepare them to thrive in a world in which attention is a commodity that is viciously and expertly hoarded.
Teaching students to manage their own attention and to focus for extended periods is, perhaps, one of the most empowering life lessons we can teach during their time with us, providing them with a significant bulwark against being manipulated in the years beyond university.

title: How to replicate Zoom's breakout room feature in Google meet
Michel Serres: Thinking in Figures
description:
A talk given by Dr Christopher Watkin in the Division of Literatures, Cultures, and Languages, Stanford University, Thursday 30 January, 2020.

After a long period of under-appreciation, Michel Serres's prescient and unique writing is now beginning to receive the attention it has long deserved. This talk explores the distinctiveness and contemporaneity of Serres‚Äôs thought, paying particular attention to the  "figures" that distinguish not only the themes he addresses, but also the way he approaches and passes between them. What emerges is a picture of a body of work radically distinct from that of his contemporaries Derrida, Deleuze and Foucault, and a set of concerns the timeliness of which is only now becoming evident.

Dr Christopher Watkin is a Senior Lecturer at Monash University, Melbourne, Australia, where he teaches across French and Literary Studies. He is the author of a number of books in modern and contemporary thought, including Phenomenology or Deconstruction? (2009), Difficult Atheism (2011), and French Philosophy Today: New Figures of the Human (2016). His latest monograph, Michel Serres: Figures of Thought, is due to be published with Edinburgh University Press in early 2020. Chris is currently working on a project interrogating the concepts of freedom and liberation in contemporary thought and society in the light of what has been called the Western ‚Äúemancipation narrative‚Äù. He blogs about philosophy and academic research at christopherwatkin.com, and you can find him on Twitter @DrChrisWatkin.

title: How does online reporting of climate change frame the question of freedom letterbox
description:
How does online reporting of climate change frame the question of freedom?
From 2010 to April 2019, 82% of references to freedom near "climate change" in online articles were about free trade.
Online media coverage frames climate change as a threat to free trade.
This influences people's willingness to acknowledge and act on climate change, because it frames climate change as a threat to freedom. And we all value freedom.
But the real relationship between climate change and freedom is  more complex than this framing suggests.

More at https://christopherwatkin.com/category/freedom-liberation-and-emancipation/

Search performed using the NOW corpus (News on the Web), which contains 7.8 billion words of data from web-based newspapers and magazines from 2010 to the present time. The corpus grows by about 140-160 million words of data each month (from about 300,000 new articles). Search performed on occurrences of "free" and "freedom" within 5 words (left or right) of "climate change". 
103 of 181 instances of "free *" in proximity to "climate change" in the NOW corpus as of 16 May 2019 refer to "free trade".

title: Derrida's theology
Derrida's ethics
description:
In this second of three episodes in the "Philosophy for Theologians" series I talk very briefly about the growing willingness to accept, from the mid 1990s onwards, that deconstruction is indeed ethical, before tackling the myth that Derrida is a relativist. I unpack the phrase ‚Äútout autre est tout autre‚Äù (‚Äúevery other is wholly other‚Äù) from Derrida‚Äôs reading of Kierkegaard on Genesis 22 and then introduce the notions of double bind and aporia in relation to Derrida's Force of Law. In the second half of the episode I reflect on ‚Äútout autre est tout autre‚Äù in relation to Colossians 1:16-17, and on the difference between law and justice in the context of absolute personality theism.

You can explore these and related questions further at audialterampartem.com

Original "Philosophy for Theologians" blurb: French intellectual Jacques Derrida (1930‚Äì2004) was one of the most important contributors to the post-modern philosophical movement. He was also one of the most notoriously difficult philosophers to understand. In this second episode of a three-part series, Dr. Christopher Watkin helps us understand Derrida‚Äôs moral philosophy. Dr. Watkin is senior lecturer in French Studies at Monash University, Australia.
Original link http://reformedforum.org/pft22/

Philosophy for Theologians aims to look critically at the problems of philosophy by considering everything in light of God's revelation. The program not only wants to address philosophical questions but also to equip you with a way to think about these questions.

title: Western Cultural Overview  The Death of God, Modernism and Existentialism
description:
This session of the 2011 European Leadership Forum in Eger, Hungary, considers Nietzsche‚Äôs account of the "death of God" in his parable of the madman, exploring what it means (and what it doesn‚Äôt mean!) that "God is dead" in Western culture. We see how the death of God leads to the death of meaning, man, and the author. We then follow this current through the modernism of the early twentieth century to the heyday of existentialism on the Parisian left bank of the 1950s, picking up themes from the thought of Jean-Paul Sartre and Albert Camus. No prior philosophical knowledge is assumed, and the session is introductory in nature. Most of the material will be familiar to those who have studied these areas at university level. Each of these sessions will include a "toolbox" section on how to appreciate and engage with the ideas covered from a Christian point of view, as well as time for discussion.

A talk outline is available here:
http://foclonline.org/sites/foclonline.org/files/outline_57.pdf

Date recorded: 22 May 2011

Original link: http://foclonline.org/talk/western-cultural-overview-death-god-modernism-and-existentialism

title: Derrida's metaphysics
description:
This first of three podcasts introduces Derrida and debunks the myth that he thinks language is meaningless or that things can mean whatever we want them to mean. It then unpacks the (in)famous phrase ‚Äúil n‚Äôy a pas de hors-texte‚Äù (‚Äúthere is nothing outside the text‚Äù) and the notions of "logocentrism" and "diff√©rance", before reflecting on the creator/creature distinction and the Trinity in relation to Derridean thought.

You can explore these and related questions further at audialterampartem.com

"Philosophy for Theologians" podcast, March 2016.

Philosophy for Theologians aims to look critically at the problems of philosophy by considering everything in light of God's revelation. The program not only wants to address philosophical questions but also to equip you with a way to think about these questions.
